content.description: ESTIMATED PERCENTAGE OF PEOPLE LIVING IN TOWNS OF MORE THAN 10,000 150016001700Northwestern EuropeEngland and Wales3.15.813.3Netherlands15.824.333.6Belgium21.118.824.3France4.25.99.2Southern EuropeSpain6.111.49.0Italy12.415.113.2Central and Eastern EuropePoland0.00.40.5Austria/Bohemia1.72.13.9Germany3.24.14.8EUROPE5.67.69.2Adapted from: Stephen Broadberry and Bishnupriya Gupta, “The Early Modern Great Divergence: Wages, Prices and Economic Development in Europe and Asia, 1500–1800,” The Economic History Review, New Series, Vol. 59, No. 1 (Feb., 2006), Table 4.
content.question: Which of the following overall trends is indicated by the data in the table?

choices.label: Europe was less urbanized in 1700 than it was in 1500.
Europe was more urbanized in 1700 than it was in 1500.
Southern Europe urbanized more rapidly than other regions of Europe did from 1500 to 1700.
The average size of European towns remained about the same in the period 1500 to 1700.

content.answer: Europe was more urbanized in 1700 than it was in 1500.

topic.text: 3.3: Continuities and Changes to Economic Practice and Development

skill.text: Skill 5.A: Identify patterns among or connections between historical developments and processes.
